medical_terms.definition: A chronic medical condition in which the blood pressure in the arteries is persistently elevated, defined as systolic pressure ≥140 mmHg and/or diastolic pressure ≥90 mmHg on at least two separate occasions
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Results from increased peripheral vascular resistance, increased cardiac output, or both; involves complex interactions between genetic, environmental, and neurohormonal factors affecting renal sodium handling, vascular tone, and sympathetic nervous system activity
medical_terms.clinical_features: Often asymptomatic; may present with headache, dizziness, blurred vision, epistaxis, or shortness of breath in severe cases
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: Based on multiple BP measurements on separate occasions; ambulatory BP monitoring recommended for confirmation; evaluation includes assessment of target organ damage and secondary causes

medical_terms.definition: A group of metabolic disorders characterized by chronic hyperglycemia resulting from defects in insulin secretion, insulin action, or both, leading to disturbances in carbohydrate, fat, and protein metabolism
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Type 1: autoimmune destruction of pancreatic beta cells leading to absolute insulin deficiency; Type 2: combination of insulin resistance and relative insulin deficiency; other types include specific genetic defects, diseases of exocrine pancreas, drug-induced
medical_terms.clinical_features: Classic symptoms: polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, weight loss; may present with complications including infections, blurred vision, fatigue, or asymptomatic hyperglycemia detected on screening
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: Fasting plasma glucose ≥126 mg/dL, OR random plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dL with symptoms, OR HbA1c ≥6.5%, OR 2-hour plasma glucose ≥200 mg/dL during OGTT; must be confirmed with repeat testing

medical_terms.definition: Myocardial cell death due to prolonged myocardial ischemia resulting from an imbalance between oxygen supply and demand, most commonly caused by rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque and subsequent thrombus formation in a coronary artery
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Atherosclerotic plaque rupture or erosion → platelet adhesion and aggregation → thrombus formation → coronary artery occlusion → myocardial ischemia → irreversible cell death beginning in subendocardium and extending transmurally
medical_terms.clinical_features: Chest pain described as pressure, squeezing, or heaviness; may radiate to jaw, neck, back, or arms; associated with dyspnea, diaphoresis, nausea, vomiting, palpitations, anxiety; may be atypical or silent in elderly, diabetics, women
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: Fourth Universal Definition of MI requires rise and/or fall of cardiac troponin with at least one value above 99th percentile URL AND at least one of: symptoms of ischemia, new ischemic ECG changes, development of pathological Q waves, imaging evidence of new loss of viable myocardium, or identification of coronary thrombus

medical_terms.definition: An acute respiratory infection affecting the pulmonary parenchyma, characterized by inflammation and consolidation of lung tissue due to infiltration of inflammatory cells and exudate into alveoli, typically caused by infectious agents
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Microaspiration of pathogens → colonization of lower respiratory tract → invasion of lung parenchyma → inflammatory response with exudation of fluid and inflammatory cells into alveoli → impairment of gas exchange → consolidation
medical_terms.clinical_features: Fever, chills, cough (productive or non-productive), pleuritic chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, tachycardia, hypoxemia; physical findings may include crackles, bronchial breath sounds, egophony, percussion dullness
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical symptoms plus radiographic evidence of new infiltrate; severity assessment using CURB-65 or PSI score; microbiological diagnosis through sputum culture, blood culture, urinary antigen tests, PCR

medical_terms.definition: A progressive and irreversible loss of kidney function over months to years, characterized by structural or functional abnormalities of the kidneys with implications for health, and classified based on cause, GFR category, and albuminuria category
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Progressive nephron loss → compensatory hyperfiltration in remaining nephrons → glomerular hypertension and hypertrophy → further nephron injury → progressive fibrosis and scarring → eventual loss of excretory, regulatory, and endocrine functions
medical_terms.clinical_features: Often asymptomatic until advanced stages; may present with fatigue, nausea, vomiting, loss of appetite, edema, hypertension, electrolyte abnormalities, anemia, bone mineral disorders, neurological symptoms
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: KDIGO criteria: abnormalities of kidney structure or function present for >3 months with implications for health, including GFR <60 mL/min/1.73m² or markers of kidney damage (albuminuria, urine sediment abnormalities, electrolyte disorders due to tubular disorders, abnormalities detected by histology, structural abnormalities detected by imaging, history of kidney transplantation)

medical_terms.definition: A supraventricular tachyarrhythmia characterized by uncoordinated atrial activation with consequent deterioration of atrial mechanical function, manifested on ECG by irregular R-R intervals and absence of distinct P waves
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Multiple reentrant wavelets propagating randomly through atrial tissue due to abnormal impulse formation and conduction; associated with atrial remodeling, fibrosis, inflammation, and autonomic influences; often triggered by ectopic foci in pulmonary veins
medical_terms.clinical_features: Palpitations, fatigue, dyspnea, dizziness, syncope, chest discomfort; may be asymptomatic; physical exam reveals irregularly irregular pulse, variable intensity of first heart sound, pulse deficit
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: ECG showing: (1) irregular R-R intervals (when atrioventricular conduction is not impaired), (2) absence of distinct repeating P waves, and (3) irregular atrial activity; may be paroxysmal, persistent, long-standing persistent, or permanent

medical_terms.definition: A group of metabolic disorders characterized by elevated levels of lipids or lipoproteins in the blood, including elevated total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, triglycerides, or low HDL cholesterol, contributing to atherosclerosis and cardiovascular disease
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Imbalance between lipoprotein production and clearance due to genetic factors, dietary habits, medical conditions, or medications; leads to accumulation of atherogenic lipoproteins in arterial walls initiating and propagating atherosclerosis
medical_terms.clinical_features: Typically asymptomatic until complications develop; may present with xanthomas, xanthelasmas, corneal arcus, or symptoms of cardiovascular disease; diagnosed through lipid profile testing
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: Based on fasting lipid profile: Total cholesterol >200 mg/dL, LDL >100-190 mg/dL (depending on risk), HDL <40 mg/dL (men) or <50 mg/dL (women), triglycerides >150 mg/dL; classification based on pattern of lipid abnormalities and underlying etiology

medical_terms.definition: A degenerative joint disease characterized by progressive loss of articular cartilage, subchondral bone remodeling, osteophyte formation, synovial inflammation, and joint dysfunction, leading to pain, stiffness, and functional impairment
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Imbalance between cartilage degradation and repair → loss of extracellular matrix → cartilage fibrillation and erosion → exposure of subchondral bone → bone remodeling and sclerosis → osteophyte formation → synovial inflammation → pain and loss of function
medical_terms.clinical_features: Joint pain exacerbated by activity and relieved by rest, morning stiffness <30 minutes, crepitus, bony enlargement, limited range of motion, joint deformity; commonly affects knees, hips, hands, and spine
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical criteria based on symptoms and signs; radiographic features include joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, subchondral sclerosis, subchondral cysts; ACR criteria available for specific joints

medical_terms.definition: A common and serious medical illness that negatively affects how you feel, the way you think, and how you act, characterized by persistent sadness and loss of interest in activities once enjoyed, accompanied by various cognitive and physical symptoms
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Complex interplay of genetic, biological, environmental, and psychological factors; involves dysregulation of monoamine neurotransmitters (serotonin, norepinephrine, dopamine), HPA axis hyperactivity, neuroinflammation, reduced neurogenesis, and structural brain changes
medical_terms.clinical_features: Depressed mood, anhedonia, significant weight change, sleep disturbance, psychomotor agitation or retardation, fatigue, feelings of worthlessness or guilt, diminished concentration, recurrent thoughts of death or suicide; symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: DSM-5 criteria: Five or more symptoms during the same 2-week period representing a change from previous functioning, with at least one symptom being either depressed mood or loss of interest/pleasure; symptoms cause clinically significant distress or impairment; not attributable to substances or other medical conditions

medical_terms.definition: A chronic condition characterized by the retrograde flow of gastric contents into the esophagus causing troublesome symptoms and/or complications, resulting from lower esophageal sphincter dysfunction, impaired esophageal clearance, and gastric abnormalities
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Transient lower esophageal sphincter relaxations, reduced LES basal pressure, impaired esophageal clearance, delayed gastric emptying, increased gastric acid secretion, and visceral hypersensitivity contribute to reflux of gastric contents and mucosal injury
medical_terms.clinical_features: Heartburn, regurgitation, chest pain, dysphagia, odynophagia, water brash, globus sensation; extraesophageal manifestations: chronic cough, laryngitis, asthma, dental erosion; may be complicated by esophagitis, stricture, Barrett's esophagus, adenocarcinoma
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical diagnosis based on typical symptoms; confirmed by response to PPI trial; objective testing with upper endoscopy, esophageal pH monitoring, or impedance-pH monitoring for atypical symptoms, refractory cases, or suspected complications

medical_terms.definition: A chronic inflammatory disorder of the airways characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, airflow obstruction, bronchial hyperresponsiveness, and underlying inflammation, with heterogeneity in clinical presentation and pathophysiology
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Chronic airway inflammation with eosinophils, mast cells, lymphocytes; epithelial damage; bronchial hyperresponsiveness; reversible airflow obstruction; airway remodeling with subepithelial fibrosis, smooth muscle hypertrophy, angiogenesis in chronic disease
medical_terms.clinical_features: Recurrent episodes of wheezing, breathlessness, chest tightness, cough (often worse at night or early morning); symptoms variable and reversible spontaneously or with treatment; physical exam may be normal between attacks or show wheezing during exacerbations
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: History of characteristic symptom patterns plus evidence of variable expiratory airflow limitation: ≥12% and 200mL increase in FEV1 after bronchodilator, OR excessive variability in twice-daily PEF over 2 weeks, OR significant increase in FEV1 after 4 weeks of anti-inflammatory treatment, OR positive bronchoprovocation test

medical_terms.definition: A complex clinical syndrome resulting from any structural or functional impairment of ventricular filling or ejection of blood, characterized by typical symptoms (e.g., breathlessness, fatigue) and signs (e.g., edema, rales) caused by cardiac dysfunction
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Initial myocardial injury → neurohormonal activation (RAAS, SNS) → ventricular remodeling → progressive ventricular dilation and dysfunction → elevated filling pressures and reduced cardiac output → end-organ hypoperfusion and congestion
medical_terms.clinical_features: Dyspnea (exertional, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal), fatigue, reduced exercise tolerance, peripheral edema, abdominal distension, weight gain; signs: elevated JVP, rales, peripheral edema, hepatomegaly, ascites, S3 gallop
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: Framingham criteria: Simultaneous presence of 2 major criteria or 1 major plus 2 minor criteria; major: paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea, orthopnea, elevated JVP, rales, cardiomegaly, pulmonary edema, S3 gallop, weight loss >4.5kg in 5 days; minor: ankle edema, night cough, dyspnea on exertion, hepatomegaly, pleural effusion, tachycardia

medical_terms.definition: A neurological deficit attributed to an acute focal injury of the central nervous system by a vascular cause, including cerebral infarction, intracerebral hemorrhage, and subarachnoid hemorrhage, representing a leading cause of disability and death worldwide
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Ischemic: Thrombotic or embolic occlusion of cerebral artery → cerebral hypoperfusion → ischemic cascade → neuronal cell death; Hemorrhagic: Rupture of cerebral vessel → mass effect, increased ICP, cerebral ischemia, neurotoxicity from blood products
medical_terms.clinical_features: Sudden onset of focal neurological deficits: weakness/numbness (face, arm, leg), confusion, speech difficulty, visual disturbance, gait disturbance, dizziness, severe headache; symptoms depend on vascular territory affected
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: Rapid neurological assessment using standardized scales (NIHSS); neuroimaging (CT or MRI) to distinguish ischemic from hemorrhagic stroke; vascular imaging, cardiac monitoring, and laboratory tests to determine etiology and guide management

medical_terms.definition: A common, preventable, and treatable disease characterized by persistent respiratory symptoms and airflow limitation that is due to airway and/or alveolar abnormalities usually caused by significant exposure to noxious particles or gases
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Chronic inflammation throughout airways, parenchyma, and pulmonary vasculature → structural changes (small airway fibrosis, emphysematous destruction) → airflow limitation and gas trapping → progressive airflow obstruction not fully reversible → ventilation-perfusion mismatch → hypoxemia and hypercapnia
medical_terms.clinical_features: Progressive dyspnea, chronic cough, sputum production, wheezing, chest tightness; may have weight loss, muscle wasting, cyanosis in advanced disease; physical exam: barrel chest, prolonged expiration, wheezing, diminished breath sounds, pursed-lip breathing
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: Spirometry showing post-bronchodilator FEV1/FVC <0.70; confirmed in appropriate clinical context (symptoms, exposure history); severity classified by FEV1% predicted, symptom burden, and exacerbation history

medical_terms.definition: A chronic systemic autoimmune disorder characterized by persistent inflammatory synovitis typically involving peripheral joints in a symmetric pattern, which can lead to progressive joint destruction, deformity, and disability, with potential extra-articular manifestations
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Genetic predisposition + environmental trigger → loss of immune tolerance → autoantibody production (RF, anti-CCP) → immune complex formation → complement activation → synovial inflammation → pannus formation → cartilage and bone destruction → joint deformity
medical_terms.clinical_features: Symmetrical polyarthritis typically affecting small joints of hands and feet; morning stiffness >1 hour; systemic symptoms: fatigue, malaise, low-grade fever; may have rheumatoid nodules, sicca symptoms, extra-articular organ involvement
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: 2010 ACR/EULAR classification criteria based on joint involvement, serology, acute phase reactants, and symptom duration; diagnosis requires score ≥6/10; early diagnosis critical to prevent irreversible damage

medical_terms.definition: A systemic skeletal disease characterized by low bone mass and microarchitectural deterioration of bone tissue, with a consequent increase in bone fragility and susceptibility to fracture, often diagnosed after a fragility fracture occurs
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Imbalance between bone resorption and formation → excessive bone loss → decreased bone mass and disrupted microarchitecture → reduced bone strength → increased fracture risk; involves complex interactions of hormonal, genetic, nutritional, and mechanical factors
medical_terms.clinical_features: Often asymptomatic until fracture occurs; may present with height loss, kyphosis, back pain from vertebral fractures; diagnosed by low-trauma fractures or DEXA scan T-score ≤ -2.5
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: DEXA scan T-score ≤ -2.5 at lumbar spine or femoral neck; or presence of fragility fracture regardless of BMD; FRAX tool used to assess 10-year fracture risk and guide treatment decisions

medical_terms.definition: A clinical syndrome resulting from deficiency of thyroid hormones, which causes a generalized slowing of metabolic processes, with a wide spectrum of clinical manifestations ranging from subtle asymptomatic disease to life-threatening myxedema coma
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Primary: Thyroid gland failure (autoimmune, iatrogenic, iodine deficiency); Secondary: Pituitary TSH deficiency; Tertiary: Hypothalamic TRH deficiency; results in reduced synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormones → decreased metabolic rate → multisystem effects
medical_terms.clinical_features: Fatigue, weight gain, cold intolerance, constipation, dry skin, hair loss, hoarseness, cognitive slowing, depression, muscle cramps, menstrual irregularities; signs: bradycardia, delayed relaxation of reflexes, periorbital edema, cool pale skin, carpal tunnel syndrome
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: Elevated TSH with low free T4 for primary hypothyroidism; low/normal TSH with low free T4 for central hypothyroidism; may have positive thyroid antibodies (TPO, TgAb) in autoimmune thyroiditis

medical_terms.definition: A condition characterized by disruption of the mucosal integrity of the stomach and/or duodenum leading to a localized defect extending through the muscularis mucosae, most commonly caused by Helicobacter pylori infection or NSAID use
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Imbalance between aggressive factors (acid, pepsin, H. pylori, NSAIDs) and defensive factors (mucus, bicarbonate, prostaglandins, mucosal blood flow); H. pylori causes chronic gastritis and alters acid regulation; NSAIDs inhibit prostaglandin synthesis
medical_terms.clinical_features: Epigastric pain (burning, gnawing, aching) that may improve or worsen with food; nausea, vomiting, bloating, belching, early satiety; may present with complications: bleeding, perforation, obstruction; physical exam may show epigastric tenderness
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical suspicion confirmed by upper endoscopy showing ulcer; testing for H. pylori (urea breath test, stool antigen, biopsy); diagnosis of complications based on clinical presentation and imaging/endoscopic findings

medical_terms.definition: The formation of a blood clot (thrombus) within a deep vein, typically in the legs, which can lead to potentially fatal complications including pulmonary embolism and post-thrombotic syndrome
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Virchow's triad: endothelial injury, stasis, hypercoagulability; thrombus formation usually begins in valve cusps of calf veins → propagation → potential embolization; inflammation and fibrosis → venous obstruction and valvular damage → chronic venous insufficiency
medical_terms.clinical_features: Unilateral leg swelling, pain, tenderness, warmth, erythema; may be asymptomatic; Homan's sign (calf pain on dorsiflexion) unreliable; Wells score used for clinical probability assessment
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: Clinical probability assessment (Wells score) plus D-dimer testing; if moderate/high probability or positive D-dimer, compression ultrasonography is diagnostic test of choice; CT venography or MR venography for suspected pelvic/abdominal DVT

medical_terms.definition: A liver infection caused by the hepatitis C virus (HCV) that can lead to both acute and chronic hepatitis, ranging in severity from a mild illness lasting a few weeks to a serious, lifelong illness that can result in cirrhosis and liver cancer
medical_terms.pathophysiology: HCV infection → acute hepatitis (often asymptomatic) → chronic infection in 55-85% → persistent hepatic inflammation → fibrosis progression → cirrhosis → hepatocellular carcinoma; involves viral evasion of immune response and direct cytopathic effects
medical_terms.clinical_features: Acute: Often asymptomatic; may have fatigue, nausea, abdominal pain, jaundice; Chronic: Typically asymptomatic until advanced liver disease; may have fatigue, arthralgias, cryoglobulinemia symptoms; extrahepatic manifestations common
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: HCV antibody screening followed by HCV RNA PCR to confirm active infection; genotype testing to guide treatment; assessment of liver fibrosis (elastography, biomarkers, biopsy); diagnosis of complications based on clinical, laboratory, and imaging findings

medical_terms.definition: A disorder of the brain characterized by an enduring predisposition to generate epileptic seizures and by the neurobiologic, cognitive, psychological, and social consequences of this condition, requiring at least two unprovoked seizures occurring >24 hours apart
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Paroxysmal excessive neuronal discharge due to imbalance between excitatory and inhibitory neurotransmission; involves ion channel dysfunction, synaptic reorganization, glial cell abnormalities, and altered neuronal networks; various etiologies including genetic, structural, metabolic, immune, infectious
medical_terms.clinical_features: Recurrent unprovoked seizures with varied manifestations depending on seizure type: impaired consciousness, motor phenomena, sensory symptoms, autonomic features, psychic symptoms; interictal period may be normal or show cognitive/psychiatric comorbidities
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: At least two unprovoked seizures occurring >24 hours apart; OR one unprovoked seizure with high probability of further seizures; OR diagnosis of an epilepsy syndrome; EEG and neuroimaging to classify and determine etiology

medical_terms.definition: A group of blood cancers that develop from lymphocytes, characterized by the malignant transformation of cells in the lymphatic system, divided into two main categories: Hodgkin lymphoma and non-Hodgkin lymphoma, with numerous subtypes
medical_terms.pathophysiology: Malignant transformation of lymphocytes → uncontrolled proliferation → accumulation in lymph nodes and other lymphoid tissues → disruption of normal immune function → potential spread to extranodal sites; involves genetic mutations, viral infections, immune dysregulation
medical_terms.clinical_features: Painless lymphadenopathy, B symptoms (fever, night sweats, weight loss), fatigue, pruritus, alcohol-induced pain; may have organ-specific symptoms from extranodal involvement; physical exam: enlarged lymph nodes, hepatosplenomegaly
medical_terms.diagnostic_criteria: Excisional lymph node biopsy with histopathology, immunohistochemistry, and molecular studies; staging with CT/PET scans, bone marrow biopsy; classification according to WHO classification of lymphoid neoplasms
